title.narrative: Boosting sustainable coffee farming and marketing through cooperatives

description.narrative: 1. Strengthen the income base of coffee smallholders and their cooperatives by: Improved coffee productivity by effective extension systems promoting GAP Strong cooperative unions and primary cooperatives that are successful in accessing finance for business development Improved domestic and international marketing of coffee 2. Generating decent employment opportunities in on-farm and off-farm coffee-related activities by: Improved coffee productivity by effective extension systems promoting GAP Strong cooperative unions and primary cooperatives that are successful in accessing finance for business development Improved domestic and international marketing of coffee

Coffee can offer substantial income to smallholders who have diversified their farming activities. This income contributes to the food and nutritional security of families and makes households resilient to the fast-changing environment. Coffee cultivation can also contribute to climate-smart agriculture especially when good agricultural and agroforestry practices are embraced protecting the soils from over fertilisation. The shade-loving coffee allows for natural protection against erosion. The coffee sector in Kenya collapsed as a result of the privatisation of the sector but it is still an important cash crop contributing to 4% of Kenya's total export value. However due to low prices coffee production is not being maximised. If a fair price is paid to farmers for example by local value addition or strong marketing practices coffee can offer a substantial income to smallholder farmers. In order to achieve this Unions can play a pivotal role in the process to boost coffee production and marketing. The coffee unions are active in the collection procurement washing grading milling roasting and marketing of coffee on the county level. Both are looking for direct market linkages within their own country but also neighbouring counties or even export opportunities. Both Unions are very active in improving their governance (on a Union as well as Primary Coop level) financial management and extension services in order to increase productivity at the farmer level. SO # 1: FOs and farmer-led enterprises improve technical and economic services to their members along the value chain: Good Agricultural Practices are promoted through a sustainable extension structure with a focus on reaching out to lead-farmers and their group in order to improve the soil structure and quality resulting in higher productivity less costly input supply and contributing to the de-acidulation of the soil. The focus will be on transformation towards (semi-) organic farming practices. SO # 2: FOs influence policies and business environments for the transformation of family farming and the development of sustainable adaptive economic initiatives and farmer-led enterprises: The Farmers Advocacy Consultation Tool (FACT) training and coaching will support both unions in conducting effective lobby trajectories at the county level and at the national level by the Unions to access public and/or private sector financial means to further invest in the coffee sector but also creating an enabling environment for direct export linkages in order to support the Kenyan farmers adding value at the local level and getting a fair price for the coffee. SO # 3: Improved access of FOs to financial services:Through financial management training and support in preparing solid business plans with the support of Agripool experts both unions will be supported to mobilize alternative means of financing such as working capital and investment funds to further expand the coffee business (besides mobilizing internal capitalization and lobby for public investment).
At a Union level Agriterra already built the capacity on governance and financial management yet continued support is needed to assist the clients in mobilizing capital to structurally improve the organisation and position in the value-chain. This approach shall be rolled out to the primary levels as well. –
Strategic Financial Management (Unions) Financial Management Training (PCs). Record keeping at farmer level and benchmarking Internal Capitalisation training
Support in business planning and lobby with financial institutions to get access to working capital and/ or investments MCCCU aims for KES 20M (€200K) as working capital to finance farm inputs to their members in 2019. KDCU aims to access KES 70M working capital for parchment advances and 7M for working capital for operations.
SO # 4: FOs are accountable organizations able to effectively perform their institutional functions:Good governance and leadership practices are understood and implemented by the leaders of the Unions and Primary cooperatives. This is key to successful and transparent decision making fair economic transactions and active participation and loyalty among the members. Improving the understanding of good governance and leadership is key at both union and primary cooperative level to ensure maximum functioning of the FO allowing for economic transaction and expansion in the agricultural business.

The generic project plan can be found under the uploaded documents. Detailed action plans per union are prepared for 2019. For 2020-2021 and 2022 detailed action plans will be developed shortly but actual updated versions will be prepared annually in close coordination with the unions. The advisory services that will be provided by Agriterra are already detailed per year and will further guide the action plans as well.
The coffee unions have many Primary Cooperatives as members. This project will focus on further professionalising about 50% of the Primary Cooperatives (30 PC) aiming to reach about 20% of the total number of individual farmer families (22.000). To select the PCs a light assessment (1 day) will be done to know the current state of the cooperative and know what intervention would be most needed to address the identified challenges in the five described programme components.
O1: Improved capacity of FOs to deliver technical and economic services and connect their members to markets
Both unions focus much on business development by 1. good extension service provision to members focussing on increased and sustainable productivity and 2. output marketing marketing support to enhance the position in the value chain value addition by further processing and branding. This will ultimately improve the business performance increase the membership and contribute to better income at farmer level. The introduction of demand-driven services and new value adding activities will lead to increased productivity quality and resilient production by members and an enhanced position in the inclusive value chain which will eventually result in better income levels at farmer level. These demand-oriented services are sustained by income generated through the PCs. (Follow up on) Sustainable Services Workshop: capacity of Extension team and lead farmers and the structure of service provision is improved Soil testing as a business training will result in affordable soil testing for small holders resulting in better soil management and higher productivity among 4% of the members in 2019 8% in 2020 16% in 2021 and gt,20% in 2022. ToT on soil management and fertility training for extension officers and few outstanding lead farmers (Agripool experts): better technical advise to farmers leading to better productivity Value creator tool: identify opportunities to add value at the level of farmer cooperative and/or union in the coffee value chain. Branding for visibility in the national market Marketing training for staff resulting in improved skills for professional handling of customers. Facilitate linkages with the export market: At least 2 successful international market linkages facilitated Participation of KCDU and MCCCU in international coffee fairs (at least 1 event per year for both organisations) Strategic Financial Management (Unions) Financial Management Training (PCs). Record keeping at farmer level and benchmarking Internal Capitalisation training Cooperative governance training and roll out to PC: Improved governance and leadership of KCDU and MCCCU. Governance and Leadership training (through ToT to local trainers) will strengthen the ownership and absorption capacity of the partners Financial management training for PC (roll out programme through ToT to local trainers) will improve financial management at the PC level and create more awareness among the supervisory board to enlarge accountability.
Marketing support services:
O2: Improved access of FOs to financial services
Cooperative development is crucial to have a successful business run by cooperatives and be loyal and trustworthy business partners for banks buyers suppliers. Good governance and financial management are the main pillars of our approach. At a Union level Agriterra already built the capacity on governance and financial management yet continued support is needed to assist the clients in mobilizing capital to structurally improve the organisation and position in the value-chain. This approach shall be rolled out to the primary levels as well. – Support in business planning and lobby with financial institutions to get access to working capital and/ or investments MCCCU aims for KES 20M (€200K) as working capital to finance farm inputs to their members in 2019. KDCU aims to access KES 70M working capital for parchment advances and 7M for working capital for operations.
O3: Improved business environment for sustainable adaptive economic initiatives and smallholder competitiveness
Majority of the coffee producers are small holders. In order to enhance competitiveness and be adaptive this project focussed specifically on the inclusiveness of youth and women. They are an important workforce and in need of decent employment either on- or off-farm. Constituting an important part of the labour force it is important to ensure their equal participation and access to services and support but also in representation. Youth participation and young leadership will be addressed with the aim to have a fair representation of youth in the board but also to support youth to be heard and seen as serious actors in the value chain that can bring a positive change and decent employment. Already established youth councils will be further supported to identify and address relevant areas of intervention such as introducing ICT innovative solutions youth engaged as service providers and entrepreneurial young farmers as a role model.
The focus on women empowerment is implemented through all activities with the objective to try and achieve participation of at least 30% women in all activities. The aim is to have more female members and empowered women in leadership positions.
Activities: - Youth trajectory (Youth Masterclass and coaching) - Female leadership training Masterclass and coaching - Youth (at least 10%) and gender (at least 30% women) quota set for all activities - Lobby activities specifically addressing youth and women needs
O4: Strengthened institutional capacities and professionalism of FOs,
All activities that will be conducted and supported by Agriterra aim to further strengthen the professionalism of the FO as well as its institutional capacities. The direct target group of advisory services are mostly board and staff of the unions and the primary cooperatives. It includes Financial Management governance and lobby capacity building.
The Farmers Advocacy Consultation Tool training supports the unions in effectively influencing both their regional and national business environment in general and the results on farm level in particular. KDCU and MCCCU already received training on FACT including a follow-up through an intensive FACT write-shop and will be supported to further roll-out FACT to members unions and PCs respectively. Through FACT trajectory the unions will be successful in lobbying with the county government (for necessary investments) and be critical sparring partners in creating an enabling environment for the development of the sector. FACT will also support the organisation to position itself stronger into the value chain.
- Farmers Advocacy Consultation Tool 2 (FACT) Training and support in the effective lobby. Result: at least 2 successful lobby trajectories conducted at county/ local level for access to inputs or finance or policy changes.
O5: Enhanced knowledge and dissemination among peers for replication and scaling-up.
- Specialized Advisory services and knowledge exchange with experts facilitated by Agriterra’s Agripool. Agriterra promotes the use of local Agripoolers or peers as well. - Through the Agripool Agriterra will facilitate multiple knowledge exchanges. These exchanges will connect the clients with Finance Governance Business Agronomic Youth Women and Lobby experts from African and or Dutch partner organisations. - The focus is on about 50% of the PC. It is expected that by realising improved business performance due to the Various project interventions the other PC will also be triggered and gain interest in changing certain practises. - Lead Farmers and will play a pivotal role in further dissemination among peers and scaling up. This project invests in uplifting their skills knowledge and willingness to share and coach others.
Linkages At the end of this project it is expected that the unions have: a. Gained access to capital and investment funds through thorough financial management support. b. Improved the quality and quantity of coffee production by providing good advisory services to the member cooperatives. c. Collected more coffee from their members hence enlarging their market share and d. Improved access to direct coffee markets such as the auction market (bulk coffee) and created some niche markets like the local market and/or speciality coffee markets.
This will result in horizontal integration in the value chain (cooperation among various unions to access the auction market) and vertical integration by establishing more direct market linkages reducing dependency on the middle-men. This trajectory is already gaining traction.
